summary: The project manager opens the meeting by going over the agenda. She explains the project, which is to create a new remote control for television that should be original, trendy, and user-friendly. The three components of completing the project will be functional, conceptual, and detailed design. They introduce themselves by going up to the white board and stating their name, role, drawing their favorite animal, and sharing their favorite characteristic about the animal. After they talk about their overall budget, they discuss what special features they want to include in this remote control that existing ones do not have. They discuss making a menu-based remote which would be less crowded with buttons and therefore stylish and sleek but functional. They end the meeting with the project manager going over the task each member is to complete before the next meeting.
actions: The marketing expert will work on user requirements specification. The interface specialist will look at the working design. The industrial designer will work on the technical functions design. They will get specific instructions when they get back to their workspace.
decisions: They will sell the remotes for twenty five Euros each. They will aim for a profit of fifty million Euros. The remotes will target the international market.
problems: The group got the idea of making a menu-based remote that would require very few buttons to operate. Although this is an original idea, one group member points out that may be too innovative and users could have difficulty learning how to operate it. They did not yet come to a decision about whether this idea should be implemented.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: HeadOfDept@ami

  Subject: Please summarise the last meeting


  Dear Colleague,

   

  Would you be so kind to report to me on the past meeting? Please hit the reply button and fill in the questions below, then click send. Please keep in mind that your notes are part of the project documentation - among other things, they will be used by myself and other staff to stay informed about the state of the project. It is therefore essential that your notes - though kept short - are of high quality. In particular:

   

    a.. Do not use any abbreviations. 
    b.. Write notes that are understandable for somebody who was not present during the meeting 
   

  The head of your department

   

   

  [ABSTRACT]   Write one paragraph of coherent text to summarize the meeting as a whole from your role's perspective.

   

   In this meeting we discussed the final disain issues, and evaluated the prototype. Then we calculated the production costs. It turned out that the estimated production costs were over the budject. Therefore, we had to slightly simplify the design, and removed some of the advanced, but non too necessary features - scroll button and the voice sampler. Since the voice sampler was also ment to be used when locating the remote control, we had to provide an alternative solution. We decided that it would just beep when the locator button that can be attched to the TV (or anywhere else for that matter) is pressed. User interface: The aspects of a computer system or program which can be seen (or heard or otherwise perceived) by the human user, and the commands and mechanisms the user uses to control its operation and input data.
E.g. Shape, size, buttons, voice-recognition,
Colour, etc.
2:
Research the interfaces of related products, mainly on the internet.
Analyse their user friendliness
Assess their appearance
Decide which features to incorporate in the design of our product.
3:
In the case of most of the remote controls the interface consists of a clutter of button functions, colors, and forms. This inconsistent use of interface is confusing and doesn't improve the use of the product.
 New user interface component – voice recognition (record up to 80 voice samples)
A spinning wheel with LC display 
A scroll button with integrated push button (such as in modern computer mouse) at the side of the remote 
Latest developments of the manufacturing division of our company – programmable speech speaker unit – add on to voice recognition
4: Personal Preferences

Keep it small
Keep it simple
Include voice recognition
Standard major buttons
Other function via menu on screen

doc.content:
Final report



Team: 	Jen (Project Manager)

Cat (Marketing Expert)

Gaurav (Industrial Design)

Maarika (User Interface Design)



Product: Television remote control



Technical specifications:

	- internal simple battery

	- rubber case, curved on 1 side, hinged to flip open

	- push buttons for power, and channels on front

	- push buttons for volume on side

	- LCD display with spinning wheel on inside for all other functions

	- advanced chip

	- voice recognition

	- separate locator to be attached to TV which will make remote ‘beep’

	 

	- yellow banana-look with black buttons and grey company logo



Product evaluation

Attractive			7

Match operating behaviour	6

Be locatable			7

Be intuitive			5

Ergonomic to reduce RSI	6

Voice control			7

Technologically innovative	6

Put fashion in electronics	7



Average			6.4



Product description:

An innovative, new-look TV remote control aimed at 15-35’s, the Real Reaction © product is in advance of trends in its spongy, vegetable-like look-and-feel. Combining a simple push button interface with the most popular remote commands and a flip-open LCD display and spinning wheel for advanced functionality, the product will revolutionise TV in this country and globally. Voice-recognition and built-in speaker increase ease-of-use and appeal to the designated target group, and the rubber casing and ergonomic design prevent damage and reduce the risk of RSI.

 

Design process:

The product was designed by a team of experts, each with his or her own speciality. The design process worked smoothly, interspersing individual work with regular meetings to consolidate knowledge gained and make key design decisions. Decision making was by consensus and all team members contributed to the process. The team worked well together and all minor differences were resolved through discussion. Technological resources (PowerPoint, laptops, whiteboards, email) were used appropriately and facilitated the smooth progression of the process.

Minutes of initial meeting



Time: 11am, 28 Jan. 05

Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID)



 

 [ABSTRACT]   



 The meeting functioned as an introduction to the team and the project. After an initial brief of the project, team members introduced themselves and their roles (see present above). The project finances were outlined, and then initial ideas for the product were briefly discussed.



	 [DECISIONS]   

	

	 No decisions were made as this was an introductory meeting.

	The initial ideas which were suggested by the marketing expert were agreed by the group - that we should go for a sleek look which fits with other products marketed by this company. This may involve having few or no buttons on the remote as many of these are rarely used anyway. 

	The user interface designer cautioned against  using a design which is too different from what consumers are used to as this will reduce the usability of the device.

	

	[ACTIONS]  

	 

	Actions to be taken:

	ID: the working design

	UID: the technical functions design

	ME: the user requirements specification  

	PM: liaise with management, prepare minutes and next meeting

Minutes of second meeting



Time: 12:05pm, 28 Jan. 05

Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID)



[ABSTRACT]   



 This meeting brought together the initial individual work of the two designers and marketing expert. Each presented their ideas on working design, technical functions design and functional design respectively - presentations can be found in the project documents folder. Discussion followed, the result of which was a decision on target group and functionality



	 [DECISIONS]  


	Target group - 15-35 – this implies incorporating voice recognition

	Design - small, sleek, sexy, but must follow some conventions for ease of use

	Functionality - volume, channel, power, menu, no teletext

	Locator – perhaps to attach to TV

	TV only – unless we can make a case to management that other things (eg video, DVD) should be supported as well, as most other models do this

	Voice recognition (we need to investigate implications of this before committing fully) – would be great if it could recognise channels, not just numbers

	

	 [PROBLEMS/ISSUES] 


	Suggestions from management were incorporated with little trouble.

	Any extra functionality will make the chip bigger. This needs to be kept in mind during design. Likewise the cost implications of greater functionality.

	The possibility of an LCD screen was not explored.

	The design should be ergonomic to prevent RSI.

	

	[ACTIONS]  

	 

	ID: components concept

	UID: user interface concept

	ME: trend watching

	PM: liaise with management, keep team updated

	 

	All to consider implications/feasibility of incorporating voice recognition and keep our target group in mind when designing.

Minutes of second meeting



Time: 14:15pm, 28 Jan. 05

Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID)



[ABSTRACT]   



This meeting focussed on the concepts of the remote control, including components, properties, materials, user interface and response to trends. Each team member presented their findings and gave reasons for their preferred design choices. The meeting resulted in consensus on design specifications.



	[DECISIONS]   


	 Technical specifications:

	- internal simple battery

	- rubber case, curved on 1 side, hinged to flip open

	- push buttons for power, volume and channels on outside

	- LCD display with spinning wheel on inside

	- voice recognition

	- advanced chip

	- sender and speaker if costs permit

	 

	- 'fruit and vegetable' colours - orange, green, maybe red, yellow, purple

	- company colours can be incorporated in button design

	

	[ACTIONS]  

	 

	ID - look and feel design - model

	UID - user interface design - model

	ME - product evaluation

	PM – final report
